congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Prohibiting the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or D1048re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran

Prohibiting the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or D1048re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House began consideration of H.R. 5711, to prohibit the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, November 17th.<P/>Considered the Swalwell (CA) motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Financial Services with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment. Further proceedings were postponed.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 114-66 shall be considered as adopted, in lieu of the amendment recommended by the Committee on Financial Services now printed in the bill.<P/>Huizenga (MI) manager's amendment (No. 1 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-818) that adds a short title and clarifies the nature of prohibited Iranian transactions; provides for a sunset of the bill's provisions upon Presidential certification that Iran has ceased support for international terrorism.<P/>H. Res. 921, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 5711) and (H.R. 5982) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 580, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 579.

The House began consideration of H.R. 5711, to prohibit the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, November 17th.<P/>Considered the Swalwell (CA) motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Financial Services with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment. Further proceedings were postponed.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 114-66 shall be considered as adopted, in lieu of the amendment recommended by the Committee on Financial Services now printed in the bill.<P/>Huizenga (MI) manager's amendment (No. 1 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-818) that adds a short title and clarifies the nature of prohibited Iranian transactions; provides for a sunset of the bill's provisions upon Presidential certification that Iran has ceased support for international terrorism.<P/>H. Res. 921, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 5711) and (H.R. 5982) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 580, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 579.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.

Prohibiting the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or D1048re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House began consideration of H.R. 5711, to prohibit the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, November 17th.<P/>Considered the Swalwell (CA) motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Financial Services with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment. Further proceedings were postponed.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 114-66 shall be considered as adopted, in lieu of the amendment recommended by the Committee on Financial Services now printed in the bill.<P/>Huizenga (MI) manager's amendment (No. 1 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-818) that adds a short title and clarifies the nature of prohibited Iranian transactions; provides for a sunset of the bill's provisions upon Presidential certification that Iran has ceased support for international terrorism.<P/>H. Res. 921, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 5711) and (H.R. 5982) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 580, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 579.

The House began consideration of H.R. 5711, to prohibit the Secretary of the Treasury from authorizing certain transactions by a U.S. financial institution in connection with the export or re-export of a commercial passenger aircraft to the Islamic Republic of Iran. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, November 17th.<P/>Considered the Swalwell (CA) motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Financial Services with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment. Further proceedings were postponed.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 114-66 shall be considered as adopted, in lieu of the amendment recommended by the Committee on Financial Services now printed in the bill.<P/>Huizenga (MI) manager's amendment (No. 1 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-818) that adds a short title and clarifies the nature of prohibited Iranian transactions; provides for a sunset of the bill's provisions upon Presidential certification that Iran has ceased support for international terrorism.<P/>H. Res. 921, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 5711) and (H.R. 5982) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 580, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 181 nays, Roll No. 579.
